episode.content: The worldwide pandemic is changing everything. While the world eagerly awaits breakthroughs, people are searching for different ways to lead fulfilling lifestyles. This new series, The Signs, takes a deep dive into the new normal unfolding in Japan. The trends we spot could be part of your tomorrow. As real-world contact is limited, technology is helping people to build and maintain relationships. New VR worlds are opening up for avatars. In this episode of The Signs, we take a closer look.
episode.description: This new series will focus on the latest movements in the age of New Normal. In this first episode, we'll visit the virtual world where people start connecting to each other by using their "avatars."
episode.subtitle: Avatars
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: COVID-19 is still plaguing people around the world. The medical field in Japan is also suffering from this new infectious disease. It's been a long battle. Amid fears of the third wave of outbreak, the challenge for society as a whole is how to balance normal medical practice with the need to deal with COVID-19 without disrupting the medical system. Now, efforts are beginning to cross medical and industrial boundaries under the outbreak. This episode focuses on fully automated PCR testing machine, VR training for medical workers, and infection-free clothing that allows for hospital visits.
episode.description: Efforts are beginning to cross medical and industrial boundaries under the outbreak. Here, you'll find the automated PCR testing machine, VR training for medical workers, and infection-free clothing.
episode.subtitle: Healthcare and Industry Unite
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: In this new episode, we will report on the new signs of "Contactless Services" that have emerged from COVID-19 disaster. In order to prevent further spread of the new coronavirus, and at the same time promote economic activities, it will be necessary to shift to the business model based on the "three-Cs avoidance" principle; closed, crowded, contact. You will find efforts to create new value in a situation that could be described as adversity.
episode.description: Could social distancing be an unlikely driver of new value in the COVID era? In a contactless world, personal and social relationships are following new paths. Look closely, and you can see the signs.
episode.subtitle: Contactless
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: Due to COVID-19 situation, the outlook for small- and medium-sized businesses -- the bedrock of the Japanese economy -- is especially grim. Amidst the turmoil, financial institutions work to support small businesses in need. Unique community-based credit unions -- working hand-in-hand with management -- are bringing new Signs of hope to companies struggling to weather the coronavirus storm.
episode.description: Amidst the pandemic, a particular Japanese style of finance is attracting attention. Unique community-based credit unions are bringing new signs of hope to local business owners struggling.
episode.subtitle: Non-Profit Banks
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: The coronavirus pandemic has upended lifestyles and economies everywhere. One vision of that reset is on the horizon. It's called green recovery. The idea is to use investments in environmental protection and social transformation to drive economic recovery. Renewable energy is a cornerstone of the green recovery concept. EVs are now playing a key role in this new challenge, not only as vehicles but also as storage batteries.
episode.description: Japan is now promoting local production of renewable energy for local consumption. EVs are now playing a key role in this new challenge, not only as vehicles but also as storage batteries.
episode.subtitle: Energizing Electric Vehicles
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: The pandemic is hitting food service hard, causing many businesses to close down. But amid the crisis, innovative food businesses are popping up. We get a closer look at new kinds of restaurants.
episode.description: The pandemic is hitting food service hard, causing many businesses to close down. But amid the crisis, innovative food businesses are popping up. We get a closer look at new kinds of restaurants.
episode.subtitle: The Evolving Food Industry
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: Due to the pandemic in 2020, nearly all live entertainment ground to a halt, including Rakugo, a traditional Japanese performing art. During the hiatus, Rakugo artists began to broadcast online, attracting subscribers and sponsors while performing for remote fans. As theaters gradually reopen, many artists attempt to reach a wider audience by balancing the real world and online performances. Explore the signs of a paradigm shift in the world of classical Japanese performing arts.
episode.description: COVID-19 dealt a major blow to RAKUGO, a traditional form of storytelling. Artists were unable to perform for live audiences, but many started to broadcast online, to attract ever broader audiences.
episode.subtitle: New Streams in Rakugo
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: The rapid increase in the use of disposable masks and to-go containers during the pandemic has made the problem of plastic waste go from bad to worse. But some Japanese companies are working to alleviate the issue. Environmentally friendly masks made of fibers used for traditional Japanese paper, which decompose in 3 months when buried in soil. Also underway is the development of plates made from recycled food waste, and an initiative to compost them after use.
episode.description: Plastic waste is rapidly increasing during the pandemic. We spotlight Japanese companies efforts to protect the environment, such as making masks form paper, and plates made of recycled food waste.
episode.subtitle: Eliminating Plastic Waste
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: Messenger RNA science has tremendously accelerated the development of effective COVID-19 vaccines. Enabling the creation of a variety of proteins inside the body, mRNAs are a promising weapon in the fight against intractable diseases such as cancer. This episode of The Signs focuses on Japanese researchers who work to create new vaccines and medicine through combining mRNAs with original technology.
episode.description: Used in COVID-19 vaccines, mRNA science is a promising weapon in the fight against intractable diseases. This episode focuses on Japanese researchers who use mRNA technology to develop new treatments.
episode.subtitle: mRNA: Medical Messenger of Hope
episode.title: The Signs

episode.content: Japan has long practiced the use of materials with sterilizing properties for everyday things and clothing. Scientific research now shows that these materials, such as extracts from indigo, known as Japan blue, and plaster used in traditional architecture, are also effective against COVID-19. Also, in the realm of the latest technology, a revolutionary virus-inhibiting lighting fixture has been developed that uses UV light that's safe for humans. In this episode, we talk to some of Japan's leading researchers about the forefront of antiviral technology.
episode.description: Research reveals traditional Japanese materials like indigo and plaster can inactivate the coronavirus. They are expected to be put to a wide range of uses in medical facilities, schools, and trains.
episode.subtitle: Frontiers in Antiviral Technology
episode.title: The Signs
